raw_text:
Weak data buffets French economy
 
 A batch of downbeat government data has cast doubt over the French economy's future prospects.
 
 Official figures showed on Friday that unemployment was unchanged at 9.9% last month, while consumer confidence fell unexpectedly in October. At the same time, finance minister Nicolas Sarkozy warned that high oil prices posed a threat to French growth. "[Oil prices] will weigh on consumer spending in the short term, and potentially on confidence," he said. World oil prices have risen by more than 60% since the start of the year as production struggles to keep pace with soaring demand.
 
 Analysts said French companies, keen to protect their profit margins at a time of rising energy costs, were reluctant to take on extra staff. "[The unemployment figures] show the main problem of the French economy: we have growth but without an improvement in employment," said Marc Touati, an economist at Natexis Banques Populaires. "Politicians must have the will and guts to solve structural unemployment with thorough reforms, otherwise in five or ten years, it will be too late." Obligatory employer contributions to worker welfare programmes mean that it costs more to hire staff in France than in many other European economies. Many economists have urged the government to stimulate employment by reducing non-wage payroll costs, and by scrapping restrictions on working hours. The French statistics agency, INSEE, expects the economy to grow by about 2.4% this year, buoyed by strong consumer spending and business investment. That is above the projected eurozone average of just above 2%.
llama3.2:1b: French government data indicates that unemployment remains high at 9.9%, while consumer confidence fell in October. Finance minister Nicolas Sarkozy warned that high oil prices could negatively impact French growth. World oil prices have risen by over 60% since January, affecting consumer spending and confidence. Analysts suggest that French companies are reluctant to hire more staff due to rising energy costs and urged politicians to reform unemployment policies to stimulate employment.
llama3.2:3b: French government data shows unemployment unchanged at 9.9%, while consumer confidence fell in October due to high oil prices, which finance minister Nicolas Sarkozy warned could weigh on growth. Economists say France's high labor costs and restrictive rules make it difficult for companies to hire staff, contributing to structural unemployment, with many urging the government to implement reforms.
gemma2:2b: France's economy faces challenges due to high oil prices, leading to increased costs for businesses and reluctance to hire new staff. Unemployment remains unchanged at 9.9%, while consumer confidence has declined.  The French government plans to stimulate employment through reforms to reduce payroll costs. Despite these challenges, the French economy is projected to grow by approximately 2.4% this year.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Weak data points to growing unemployment in France. Sarkozy warns that high oil prices pose a threat. French companies are hesitant to increase staff due to rising energy costs. Many economists suggest reducing non-wage payroll costs and scrapping working hours restrictions to stimulate employment.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Weak data suggest worsening unemployment in France along with high oil prices posing a threat to growth. French companies are reluctant to hire more due to rising energy costs. The government needs to reduce non-wage payroll costs, such as employer contributions for welfare programs and working restrictions, to boost employment.
qwen2.5:3b: Weak government data casts doubt on France's economic prospects. Unemployment remains unchanged at 9.9%, while consumer confidence fell in October. Finance minister Nicolas Sarkozy warned of a threat from high oil prices, which could weigh on spending and confidence. French companies are reluctant to hire due to rising energy costs, leading to a problem of growth without employment improvement. Analysts suggest the government should implement reforms to reduce non-wage payroll costs and remove working hour restrictions to stimulate employment. The INSEE expects a 2.4% economy growth this year, above the eurozone average.

smollm:1.7b: The text summarizes the weak data buffets French economy has faced in recent months, with high unemployment rates and low consumer confidence. The main problem lies in the lack of growth, which is attributed to high energy prices and structural issues within the economy. Analysts emphasize that France needs a comprehensive reform plan to address these problems and ensure sustainable economic growth in the future.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize the given text concisely. Let me read through it first.

The main points are: the French economy's weak performance in data shows potential for trouble. Unemployment stayed at 9.9%, consumer confidence dropped unexpectedly. The finance minister warned about high oil prices affecting growth. Analysts say companies struggle with extra staff due to rising costs, and governments need to reduce non-wage payroll costs or cut hours. Insee predicts a growth of around 2.4% despite the data being weak.

I should make sure I include key ideas like unemployment, consumer confidence, high oil prices, analyst views, government strategies, and economic outlook.

Putting it all together in concise terms without extra details.
</think>

The French economy's weak performance in recent government data suggests potential challenges for growth. Unemployment remained stable at 9.9%, while consumer confidence fell unexpectedly. Nicolas Sarkozy warned of the impact of high oil prices on French growth. Analysts noted that French companies are reluctant to take on extra staff amid rising energy costs, fearing a structural unemployment. They advised governments to reduce non-wage payroll costs and consider cutting working hours to support employment efforts. INSEE projects a 2.4% growth this year, surpassing the eurozone average of around 2%.
tinyllama:1.1b: French economic data highlights uncertain future prospects amid rising oil prices and unequal workforce growth. Batch of downbeat government statistics revealed that unemployment remained stagnant at 9.9% last month, while consumer confidence fell despite high oil prices posing a threat to French growth. Analysts warn that companies are reluctant to take on extra staff due to lack of employment improvements and structural unemployment, urging politicians to stimulate the labour market through job creation measures. The economy is projected to grow by 2.4% this year, with strong consumer spendings and business investments expected. However, the eurozone's average growth is below 2%.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In summary, according to official French government data, unemployment levels have remained unchanged at 9.9% and consumer confidence has fallen unexpectedly in October; with finance minister Nicolas Sarkozy warning that high oil prices are posing a threat to French growth. The lack of job creation has prompted economists to call for significant reforms, including employer contributions to worker welfare programmes and reduced non-wage payroll costs.

The French statistics agency, INSEE, expects the economy to grow by 2.4% this year, above the projected eurozone average.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Weak economic data has raised concerns about France's future growth. Unemployment remained at 9.9%, and consumer confidence declined in October. Finance Minister Nicolas Sarkozy warned that high oil prices could hurt consumer spending and confidence. Rising energy costs have made companies hesitant to hire, leading to jobless growth. Economist Marc Touati stressed the need for structural reforms to address unemployment. High employer contributions make hiring costly, and economists suggest reducing payroll costs and easing work restrictions. Despite these challenges, INSEE forecasts 2.4% growth for the year, surpassing the eurozone average.
stablelm2:1.6b: Downbeat government data cast doubt over France's economic prospects, with unemployment unchanged at 9.9% and unexpected falls in consumer confidence. Finance minister Nicolas Sarkozy warned that high oil prices pose a threat to French growth. Unemployment is the main problem for France's economy; employers must reduce non-wage employee contributions to welfare programs. The economy is expected to grow by about 2.4% this year, above the eurozone average and outpacing projections for 2011.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
French economic data indicates potential challenges for its growth. Unemployment remains at 9.9%, unaltered from the previous month, while consumer confidence plummeted in October due to high oil prices. France's finance minister, Nicolas Sarkozy, warned that escalating oil costs would negatively impact both short-term consumer spending and overall economic confidence. Since January, global oil prices have surged by over 60%, exacerbated by insufficient production to meet burgeoning demand.

Economists note that French companies, aiming to preserve profit margins amidst rising energy expenses, are cautious about expanding their workforce. Marc Touati, an economist at Natexis Banques Populaires, emphasized the primary issue: growth without substantial employment improvement. He advocated for political determination to address structural unemployment via comprehensive reforms.

French labor laws contribute to higher costs when hiring staff due to mandatory employer contributions towards worker welfare programs. Consequently, the French statistics agency, INSEE, predicts a 2.4% economic expansion this year, surpassing the projected eurozone average of just over 2%. Nonetheless, many experts urge the government to stimulate employment by decreasing non-wage payroll expenses and eliminating restrictions on working hours.
reference: "[The unemployment figures] show the main problem of the French economy: we have growth but without an improvement in employment," said Marc Touati, an economist at Natexis Banques Populaires."[Oil prices] will weigh on consumer spending in the short term, and potentially on confidence," he said.At the same time, finance minister Nicolas Sarkozy warned that high oil prices posed a threat to French growth.The French statistics agency, INSEE, expects the economy to grow by about 2.4% this year, buoyed by strong consumer spending and business investment.Analysts said French companies, keen to protect their profit margins at a time of rising energy costs, were reluctant to take on extra staff.
